abstract.p: Robert B Harris letter opposes American Federation of Teachers proposal to add fifth year of high school, and suggests that school day and school year be lengthened instead (July 7 editorial)

block.p: I agree that the proposal by the American Federation of Teachers to add a fifth year to high school is inadequate (''Recipe for Weaker Schools,'' editorial, July 7). I suggest instead that the school day and the school year be lengthened.

I agree that the proposal by the American Federation of Teachers to add a fifth year to high school is inadequate (''Recipe for Weaker Schools,'' editorial, July 7). I suggest instead that the school day and the school year be lengthened.

I propose that the day start at 8 a.m. and end at 4:30 or 5 p.m., Monday through Friday, and that the school year begin in mid-August and end in mid-July. There could be a break for the week around Christmas and another the week around Easter.

The advantages of this schedule would include less free time for students to get into trouble; more time to develop skills; more time to explore academic material in depth; improved academic achievement; and higher completion rates.
The United States has the fewest school days of any industrialized country, and it shows.
ROBERT B. HARRIS Lancaster, Calif., July 7, 2000
